snippet: In blind tennis, invented in Japan and spreading in the United States, players rely on their hearing to follow the trajectory of a foam ball that rattles when it bounces or is struck.
abstract: Burgeoning sport of blind tennis--tennis for the visually impaired--requires players to rely on their hearing to follow the trajectory of a foam ball that rattles when it bounces or is struck; sport, invented in Japan, is spreading among enthusiasts in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In blind tennis, invented in Japan and spreading in the United States, players rely on their hearing to follow the trajectory of a foam ball that rattles when it bounces or is struck.

headline.seo: A Game of Tennis Tests Notions of Blindness
headline.main: Hitting the Court, With an Ear on the Ball
headline.print_headline: Hitting the Court, With an Ear on the Ball
